title: NASA's asteroid-slamming DART mission completely changed the shape of its target | Flipboard
text: NASA's asteroid-slamming DART mission completely changed the shape of its target NASA's DART spacecraft seems to have completely reshaped asteroid Dimorphos after violently crashing into it in Sept. 2022 Scientists have discovered … [Kenneth Gentry](/@Lonewolfkg) flipped this story into [Science, Sci-Fi And Cyberpunk](/@lonewolfkg/science-sci-fi-and-cyberpunk-nm5nvbouz)•11h Related storyboards Related articles [A baby star's planet-forming disk has 3 times more water than all of Earth's oceans](/@quickflipper/explorology-ni7huku8z/a-baby-star-s-planet-forming-disk-has-3-times-more-water-than-all-of-earth-s-oce/a-MKaRrj--Sd6m3T2nJkJqZg%3Aa%3A148343087-93f0cf94d5%2Fspace.com) "I had never imagined that we could capture an image of oceans of water vapor in the same region where a planet is likely forming." It traveled millions of miles through space and deliberately crashed into the Dimorphos asteroid, all in an attempt to change its rotational speed. It caused a catastrophic change to the surface of the asteroid, however, experts now say the asteroid could be healing.
